awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Influence of phosphorus deficiency on enigmatic biological methane production in oxic freshwater lakes
awd_abstract_narration:
Atmospheric levels of methane have risen 150% since the Industrial Revolution, and continue to increase.  Although energy sector and agricultural sources are major contributors, natural microbiological sources account for roughly half of total global methane emissions.  Microbial methane production has long been assumed to be an anoxic process, carried out only under conditions of extremely low to zero oxygen. Recent research has demonstrated the potential for microbial methane production to occur in oxygenated upper waters of lakes and oceans through a previously unappreciated metabolic pathway present in microorganisms.  Under conditions of phosphorus deficiency, certain bacteria can utilize otherwise unreactive organic molecules known as methylphosphonates to meet their phosphorus requirements, releasing methane in the process.  The extent to which this mechanism supports the out-gassing of methane from lakes to the atmosphere is unknown, as are the consequences of changing environmental conditions upon it.  This project will address this knowledge gap by investigating the distributions, rates of and controls on aerobic methane production in Flathead Lake and 18 other Montana lakes of varying phosphorus deficiency status.  Because atmospheric deposition of pollutant nitrogen and deliberate measures to curtail phosphorus inputs to lakes can both lead to phosphorus deficiency, it is crucial that we know whether these factors may have the unexpected consequence of enhancing methane emissions.  This research will also directly support the education, field and laboratory experiences of graduate and undergraduate students and will provide training to local high school teachers from Native American (Kootenai and Salish) tribal lands.

This project will evaluate temporal and spatial variability in microbially-mediated, oxic methane production across lakes with varying phosphorus availability in western Montana. It is guided by the overarching hypothesis: diffusive effluxes of methane from oxic freshwater lakes are directly influenced by the nature and severity of ecosystem nutrient (nitrogen, phosphorus) deficiencies. A combination of observational and experimental approaches employing chemical, stable isotopic, metagenomic and PCR-based gene analyses will be used to examine: 1) time and space variability in the concentration, stable isotope composition, and net production of methane in freshwater lakes in Montana, focusing on Flathead Lake; 2) The extent to which microbial methylphosphonate degradation results in net production of methane in these lakes; 3) The functional diversity, abundances, and transcriptional activities of microorganisms involved in both phosphonate and methane cycling; and 4) How the stoichiometry (specifically nitrogen:phosphorus ratios) of aquatic nutrient (inorganic and total) pools influences oxic methane production and expression of methane cycling functional genes. The study will provide a systematic evaluation of microbial methane sources and the potential contribution of methylphosphonate degradation as a source of methane in oxic freshwater lakes. Results from this project will provide new insights and advance current understanding of coupled interactions between carbon and phosphorus cycling in freshwater lake habitats.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Humanity has a love/hate relationship with methane (CH4).  The simplest hydrocarbon, CH4 is the major component of the natural gas we rely on for a fifth of global energy production.  Yet, CH4 is also a potent greenhouse gas whose rising atmospheric concentration contributes to climate warming and its associated environmental and societal impacts.  Methane comes from both natural and human-made sources that are in some cases not well constrained.  Among natural sources, the emission of microbially-produced CH4 from freshwater environments is thought to be a significant component of the global CH4 budget, but estimates of its magnitude vary widely.

Canonically, the production of CH4 by microbes (methanogenesis) was thought to be carried out exclusively within environments devoid of oxygen; aquatic methanogenesis was therefore assumed to be mostly relegated to the sediments, where oxygen becomes progressively depleted with depth.  However, for decades it has been observed that the well-oxygenated upper water columns of both oceans and freshwater lakes often contain more methane than can be readily explained by exchange with the air and transport from the sediments.  The solution to this methane paradox has been the subject of vigorous debate among researchers.

Our project sought to shed light on an unconventional and somewhat controversial CH4-generating microbial process in Flathead Lake, Montana, where preliminary measurements had revealed shallow subsurface CH4 accumulation in fully-oxygenated waters in summer.  Recent studies in the open ocean had informed us that CH4 might be microbially produced from methylphosphonate (MPn) - an uncommon organic molecule containing reduced phosphorus - under conditions of extreme inorganic phosphate scarcity.  We posited that the very low phosphate levels in Flathead Lake would similarly select for microbes capable of using MPn as a phosphorus source for nutrition, thereby generating CH4 as a by-product, and that this process would significantly contribute to the net emission of CH4 from the lake to the atmosphere.

Our interdisciplinary approach included: (1) time- and depth-resolved measurements of CH4 and associated physical, chemical and biological parameters over three years; (2) analyses of the stable isotopes of the carbon (13C) and hydrogen (2H) atoms in the CH4 molecule, which can provide "fingerprints" of methane sources and sinks; (3) metagenomic characterization of water column microbial communities (who is there?) and genes crucial to key metabolisms (what could they be doing?); (4) targeted incubation experiments probing nutrient (nitrogen and phosphorus) impacts on oxic CH4 generation; and (5) sampling and rate measurements of surface waters of 24 additional lakes, to place the CH4 dynamics and responsible microbial players observed in Flathead Lake into the broader context of relative supplies of nitrogen and phosphorus to lake ecosystems.

We found that the genetic potential for oxic CH4 production exists among diverse microorganisms not only in Flathead Lake but commonly throughout the lakes studied.  Nevertheless, oxic CH4 production remains low and appears responsible for only a minor fraction of methane emissions from Flathead Lake to the atmosphere.  Our experiments revealed that CH4 production by the ecosystem as a whole did not respond to nitrate or phosphate addition, but that certain organisms did respond to the addition of MPn, and these appeared to be held in check by lack of both the MPn substrate itself and of the organic carbon they require as a source of energy.  While low phosphorus does appear to favor the microbes that can use MPn for their phosphorus supply, this pathway does not seem to be particularly important to the methane budget of our primary study lake.  These findings suggest that more attention needs to be paid to alternative explanations to solve the CH4 paradox.  In future studies, we will be trying to better separate the often complex physical CH4 transport processes from other microbiological CH4-generating pathways yet to be appreciated.

Crucial to the success of our project was the involvement of early career scientists (postdoctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students); these young scholars led the authorship of four peer-reviewed publications originating from this research project, and most have moved on to advanced degree programs or faculty positions.  In addition to postdoctoral and student support, we provided funds to partially offset the costs incurred by students participating in the Aquatic Microbial Ecology summer course held at Flathead Lake Biological Station (FLBS).  We also engaged the public by hosting two workshops at FLBS: one for local area science teachers and the other for high school students participating in a Salish- Kootenai College STEM program for young Native Americans.
